field_reports.description:
The rainstorm "Hans" passed Northern Europe this week, and hit parts of Southern Norway with heavy rainshowers up to 120 mm per day, startin on the evening of Monday the 7th of August. Raining continued through the night and through the following two days, showering large areas with the same amount in 24 hours as the normal amount in the month of August alltogether.

Many municipalities were severely affected, leading to flooding, land and mud slides, and disruption of critical infrastructure in large parts of inland Southern Norway. All main roads from Oslo going North and Northwest were closed due to slides and flooding, as well as rail connections and smaller roads, isolating towns and villages. Several days after the rains subsiding, the large amounts of water is still affecting huge areas, now mainly with flooding, as the risk of land slides is now more moderate.

The situation has been, and still is, serious, leading to large evacuations of several thousand people, as well as destroyed infrastructure, reduced accessibility to critical services for the population. There is still a risk to life and health, and this will carry on for the next few days as the flooding continues in to early next week.
field_reports.summary: NOR: Flood - 2023-08 - Extreme weather, flooding and land slides in Southern Norway

results.name: NOR: Flood - 2023-08 - Extreme weather, flooding and land slides in Southern Norway
results.summary: The rainstorm "Hans" passed Northern Europe this week, and hit parts of Southern Norway with heavy rainshowers up to 120 mm per day, startin on the evening of Monday the 7th of August. Raining continued through the night and through the following two days, showering large areas with the same amount in 24 hours, that is a normal amount in the month of August alltogether. Many municipalities were severely affected, leading to flooding, land and mud slides, and disruption of critical infrastructure in large parts of inland Southern Norway. All main roads from Oslo going North and Northwest were closed due to slides and flooding, as well as rail connections and smaller roads, isolating towns and villages. Several days after the rains subsiding, the large amounts of water is still affecting huge areas, now mainly with flooding, as the risk of land slides is now more moderate. The situation has been, and still is, serious, leading to large evacuations of several thousand people, as well as destroyed infrastructure, reduced accessibility to critical services for the population. There is still a risk to life and health, and this will carry on for the next few days as the flooding continues in to early next week.

field_reports.description:
As of early July, more than 20 000 Ukrainian refugees have been registered in Norway. During the last three months, Norway has seen a decrease in the number of refugees that are arriving in Norway. Now, approximately 70-80 refugees are registered from Ukraine every day. More than 1/3 of the refugees have been given permanent residence, while many are still waiting for a permanent residence and are living at shelters. As there have been fewer arrivals than what was expected, the Norwegian authorities are now closing many of the temporary shelters that were put up in March and April.

Volunteers from the Norwegian Red Cross continue to be present for refugees and are providing activities at shelters. Numbers from last week indicate that volunteers were active in 16 out of 18 Red Cross-districts (regions). 499 volunteers were actively engaged in support for refugees, such as providing activities and providing practical assistance. As many refugees have stayed at shelters throughout the summer, the Norwegian Red Cross has been present with activities. Activities such as summer camps, amusement parks, while maintaining Norwegian speaking sessions. These activities will continue into the fall. As refugees are being given a permanent residence, many local branches are currently engaged in making sure that refugees have access to local activities provided by the Norwegian Red Cross where they live.
field_reports.summary: NOR: Population Movement - 2022-02 - Norway: Ukraine Refugee Situation #7 (2022-08-08)

field_reports.description:
Volunteers from The Norwegian Red Cross continue to be present for refugees arriving in Norway, at shelters and asylum centers across the country. Volunteers are still present and actively aiding at 16 out of 18 districts. As of week 27, there was a total of 522 volunteers present at 62 shelters/asylum centers. The Norwegian government has reported that a total of 21 512 refugees have applied for asylum in Norway. Over 18 000 been granted temporary asylum/protection. The Norwegian government is working to provide all Ukrainian refugees a permanent residence in municipalities throughout the country. 
The Red Cross volunteers are providing the refugees with activities, language exchange and practical help at all stages of the process.
field_reports.summary: NOR: Population Movement - 2022-02 - Norway: Ukraine Refugee Situation #6 (2022-07-13)

field_reports.description:
As of early June, close to 20 000 Ukrainian refugees have been registered in Norway. During the last two months, Norway has seen a decrease in the number of refugees that are arriving in Norway. Now, approximately 50-60 refugees are registered from Ukraine every day. About 1/3 of the refugees have been given a more permanent residence, while many are still waiting for a permanent residence and are living at shelters. As there have been fewer arrivals than what was expected, the Norwegian authorities are now closing many of the temporary shelters that were put up in March and April. 

Volunteers in the Norwegian Red Cross continue to be present for refugees and are providing activities for the refugees at shelters. Numbers from last week indicate that volunteers were active in 17 out of 18 Red Cross-districts (regions). 1 095 volunteers were actively engaged in support for refugees, such as providing activities and providing practical assistance. As many refugees will continue to live at shelters throughout the summer, the Norwegian Red Cross assumes that activities at shelters will continue for some time. As refugees are being given a permanent residence, many local branches are currently engaged in making sure that refugees have access to local activities provided by the Norwegian Red Cross where they live. 

In May, the Norwegian Red Cross discontinued (terminated) its crisis management, and is now handling the situation through our ordinary organisation.
field_reports.summary: NOR: Population Movement - 2022-02 - Norway: Ukraine Refugee Situation #5 (2022-06-16)

contacts.name: Anders Thorheim
contacts.title: Head of Domestic Crisis Management Team

field_reports.description: Volunteers in The Norwegian Red Cross continues to be present for refugees arriving in Norway, at shelters/asylum centers across the country. As of week 16, volunteers were present at shelters/asylum centers in 16 out of 18 provinces (districts). A total of 1 261 volunteers were present at 56 shelters/asylum centers. The Norwegian government believes that approximately 20 000 refugees have arrived in Norway from Ukraine. As of early May, a little more than 15 000 refugees have applied for temporary asylum in Norway. The immigrant authorities and the government are now working to ensure that the refugees will be provided a perminent residence in a muncipiality as soon as possible, and believe that they will be able to give a permanent residence to all of the refugees that have now arrived before the summer. During the last few weeks, there has been a decrease in the number of refugees arriving in Norway from Ukraine. The government believes that we will continue to see refugees arriving, and that Norway will receive between 25 000 - 35 000 refugees from Ukraine throughout the year.
field_reports.summary: NOR: Population Movement - 2022-03 - Norway: Ukraine Refugee Situation #4 (2022-05-03)

contacts.name: Anders Thorheim
contacts.title: Head of Unit, Disaster Preparedness and Emergency

field_reports.description: As of April 22th, 2022, the Norwegian immigrant authorities believe that there are approximately 15 000 refugees from Ukraine that have arrived in Norway. During the past week, the number of refugees arriving in Norway have decreased (around 100 daily, as opposed to 500 daily in March). As of April 19th, volunteers from the Norwegian Red Cross were present at shelters/asylum reception centres in 15 out of 18 districts (regions).  1 261 volunteers are currently present at 56 shelters/asylum reception centres (out of a total of 107 shelters/asylum reception centres). Volunteers continue to provide practical support to the reception centres and to be present for the refugees residing in Norway. During the Easter holiday last week, volunteers brought refugees out on trips, such as a boat trip in Rogaland county.
field_reports.summary: NOR: Population Movement - 2022-02 - Norway: Ukraine Refugee Situation #3 (2022-04-22)

contacts.name: Anders Thorheim
contacts.title: Head of Domestic Crisis Management Team

field_reports.description:
The Norwegian Red Cross have continued to intensify its work to assist refugees arriving in Norway due to the armed conflict in Ukraine. As of March 29th 2022, volunteers from the Norwegian Red Cross are present at 23 reception centres/emergency shelters across the country. Volunteers are assisting the government, and are providing practical support and psychososial support to refugees that are arriving in Norway. Across the country, local branches have administered donations and distributed clothes, shoes and sanitary products to the newly arrived refugees. 

Our main focus is to be present to provide relief and support to refugees, provide information about the Red Crossâ€™ tracing programme and to ensure that there are activities for children and adults at the shelters. The overall objective is to ensure that the arrival in Norway is as dignified and positive as it can be during the current circumstances. 

Volunteers have also continued their presence at the National Arrival Centre in Norway. The Norwegian Red Cross is preparing to be present at all shelters/reception centres across Norway.

The Norwegian Red Cross have received mutiple requests from refugees who wants assistance in reaching their family members. The Norwegian Red Cross is working with the CTA who coordinates and monitores searches when possible. 


Currently, the Norwegian Red Cross is preparing to upscale its local activities to ensure that refugees will be offered to partake in local activities once they have been given a more permanent residence.
field_reports.summary: NOR: Population Movement - 2022-02 - Norway - Ukraine: Refugee Situation #2 (2022-03-29)

contacts.name: Anders Thorheim
contacts.title: Head of Domestic Crisis Management Team

field_reports.description:
After the military invasion of Ukraine on February 24th 2022, The Norwegian Red Cross has worked intensively to prepare it's domestic response to assist refugees that are arriving in Norway and that are in need of immediate assistance. As of March 16th, just above 2000 refugees have been registered seeking asylum in Norway from February 24th to March 14th. This number includes applicants for asylum seekers from different countries than Ukraine, however it is predominantly refugees from Ukraine that are arriving. 

The immigration authorities have estimated that 35 000 asylum seekers will arrive in Norway during 2022, howevert this does not include asylum seekers that arrive as part of an organised response or initiatives coordinated between countries to relieve the burden in Ukraine and in neighbouring countries. All asylum seekers that are Ukranian citizens and that arrive in Norway, are automatically awared refugee status in Norway. This applies also to asylum seekers in Ukraine that had a refugee status prior to February 24th, 2022. Persons that prior to February 24th did not have a refugee status in Ukraine og in neighbouring countries, will have to apply for a refugee status in accordance with the ordinary mechanisms. 

The Norwegian Red Cross estimates that there are more refugees in Norway as of present than those that have been registered as asylum seekers with the immigration authorities. Some Ukranian citizens have arrived and are living with friends and family, and have yet to be registered. The number of total arrivals since February 24th, is currently not known. 

The Norwegian Red Cross is working intensively to be present for refugees arriving in Norway. As of March 16th, volunteers from The Norwegian Red Cross are present at four reception centres where refugees are temporarily staying. As shelters and reception centres are being prepared across Norway, our volunteers are standing by, ready to assist as soon as it is needed. Volunteers have also been present at the National Arrival Centre in RÃ¥de since February 24th, where all refugees that arrive in Norway are registered. As of March 16th, refugees get registered in their local police districts, which we assume will lead to many more Ukrainian citizens being registered with the authorities. 

The Norwegian Red Cross is now preparing to be present at all shelters/reception centres in Norway where refugees arrive. We are also currently working hard to provide information to our volunteers about what is needed, to prepare guidelines and making necessary courses available for our volunteers. The Norwegian Red Cross are also currently being contacted by many in the population and businesses who wants to donate medical aid, clothes and other items, and who wants to provide aid to refugees that are arriving. We are currently coordinating our response in close dialogue with the Norwegian Immigrant Authorities and other volunteer organisations and working to assess the humanitarian needs of those who are arriving, and determining how we can best be of assistance to the government to coordinate our response effectively and ensure that those that are arriving are taken care of both initially and in a longer time-perspective.
